A sinister doctor and his growing  
army of skeletons I drew recently!  
Name: Dr. Floridius Ohgden,  
Medical Practitioner and Necromancer   
Floridius began his career as a  
surgeon before becoming an adventurer as he sought a method of eternal life for  
those not blessed with immortal flesh to go along with their immortal souls.  
This search led the doctor down a dark path as he sought out the secrets of life  
and death through experimentation. He would partner up with a rogue doctor  
running an illegal vivisection clinic where subjects were surgically  
experimented upon for increasing the pair’s medical knowledge. Eventually  
Floridius was arrested and served time in a Waterdeep prison for his crimes and  
his partner and instructor disappeared without a trace. After years of  
imprisonment, he was released and made for the fortress of Candlekeep where he  
would begin his studies anew. In exchange for his stay there he taught a class  
on biology and anatomy often performing vivisections on creatures for  
demonstrations... This was not a popular class for many reasons.  
After months in Candlekeep, Floridius  
met a party of adventurers who were seeking a method to transition to the Nine  
Hells to track down a rogue angel who became an archduke of hell. Floridius saw  
this as an opportunity to study the immortal flesh of devils to further his  
studies, and so he requested to tag along, offering his medical expertise to  
the group as well as his skills with small blades to act as an excellent rogue.  
The Hells ended up teaching the  
mad doctor quite a lot on immortality, but he was also falling further into the  
depths of corruption as he had met with and exchanged knowledge for knowledge  
with a bound and then freed flesh-shaping demon. The demon taught Floridius the  
art of fleshcraft and how to graft monster components onto himself and others.  
After the party left the Hells, Floridius  
had multiple journals of notes on the study of immortality via fleshcraft,  
surgical replacement of organs, and other less than savory means. But he is no  
god, and thus his control of the immortal soul and its binding to mortal flesh  
is limited. So, his next goal was clear: transcend the limitations of his  
mortal coil, perform the ultimate necromantic rituals to bind his soul to an  
object, and transplant his organs to a fleshcrafted golem. With this he would  
become a lich like no other; an immortal flesh golem with the knowledge to  
grant this gift unto others. However, the pursuit of such ability has forever  
changed the mad doctor and his studies and research have no place in  
civilization.  
What do you think? :)

The Conclave basically treats magic like it's religion - the thing it holds above all else, even the laws of the land. In some cases, specific mages in the books describe magic as being their love - a thing they desire and wish to protect.

In the example you give, yes the Orders would likely want to preserve the spellbook of a powerful former mage if they turn renegade (which siding with Sargonnas would likely mean, as it means turning from the three gods of magic).

In terms of how it fits societal laws, the point is that there is no law greater than the preservation of magic. If a person is a threat to magic, they must be destroyed. If there is an item of great magical power (that isn't a threat to their existence), it must be preserved. Etc.

Possibly. I suppose it would depend on whether or not the mage in question was notable, or whether that particular spellbook mattered.

28.author: Fosco_Toadfoot

I always tell people if you can read Goldilocks and the Three Bears to a toddler, with different voices for each character, you've got everything you need.

An NPC "voice" just needs to be some different way of talking that makes the character different from the narration. An accent, shifting up or down in pitch, talking faster or slower, articulating or mumbling, etc.

I like the actor method because it gives you something in your head to keep you on track. So if the players talk to the merchant they met a month ago, I don't have to remember their voice was a little higher, speaking urgently and directly. I just think "oh, that's the guy who talks like Steve Buscemi".

But if I ever told the players it was Steve Buscemi, they'd laugh at me for weeks and tell me it's the worst Buscemi impression they'd ever heard.

It's just like a bookmark to help you break up your normal narrative voice.

36.author: chimericWilder
36.body:
See, the view on Tiamat that you describe is actually not at all so far out of line—but not because of anything in Fizban's. 

I do not believe anything is written of it anywhere, but if you take the view that Io is the one true creator, and that the material plane is his gift to dragonkind, meant first and foremost for them, and that after Io's death at the hands of the primordials, dragons no longer had a true caretaker deity precisely because of Tiamat and Bahamut's complete inability to agree on anything, the case is that in the meantime all these other gods have shown up and added their own creations to the prime material, and those creations are then getting uppity—not because of any divine war, which never happened, but simply because they are mortals who are inconvenienced by dragonkind, and start to take the land and treasures that belong to the dragons...

Io's view on the other gods and their creations was permissive and neutral-cooperative, taking the side of both dragons and other mortals in equal measure, albeit with the ultimate concern being to further dragon interests in the long run. You then might say that Bahamut and Tiamat inherited those traits, but split and fanatically extremist.

With that context in mind, Tiamat's view is to be *furious* that these mortal pretenders dare to harm dragon interests, and more importantly, that the Prime Material Plane and everything upon it belongs to her by right of inheritance—and although she is still evil and filled with hate, she is not wrong. She then views Bahamut as a weak-willed pushover all too eager to give away what he should have rightfully inherited from Io. Thus, Tiamat may be greedy and covetousness... but she kind of has a divine right to be so, because she is the closest thing to a true heir that the prime material has. Which only makes it extra bitter to be stuck on Avernus.

Just wearing wet clothes doesn't count.

79.author: preiman790
79.body: So here's the thing, you know how that spell specifically says that, have you noticed that most spells don't say that?  A wall of sufficient width does stop the ability to detect magic, that doesn't mean that magic can't pass through walls that thick, just that walls that thick render the detection spell non-effective. The idea is that detect magic works kind of like an x-ray, that's also why lead stops it from working. it's a limitation of the spell not of magic

79.author: marcus_gideon
79.body:
*mumble cough*

[https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/phb/spellcasting#AClearPathtotheTarget](https://www.dndbeyond.com/sources/phb/spellcasting#AClearPathtotheTarget)

>A Clear Path to the Target  
>  
>To target something, you must have a clear path to it, so it can’t be behind total cover.  
>  
>If you place an area of effect at a point that you can’t see and an obstruction, such as a wall, is between you and that point, the point of origin comes into being on the near side of that obstruction.

That's a blanket rule for all spells. You can't cast anything that requires targeting if there's an obstacle in the way.

Detection spells have that specific wording about lead walls and such b/c they aren't targeted in the same way. They're an exception to the rule, not evidence that the rule doesn't exist.

So yeah, "most magic has no problem passing through walls" is false. Most magic cannot pass through walls, with some exceptions.

But your other point is the better one. Walls and such are solid obstacles. Water is just another medium to move through. And nothing in the rules ever says that spell energy follows the rules of aerodynamics. So they are not hindered by moving through thicker water than they are through thinner air.

79.author: preiman790
79.body: I would argue that that rule suggests that you cannot target some thing that you cannot perceive or have a direct path to, but that doesn't suggest that magic can't pass through walls, which is what the OP was arguing, more that walls are a specific impediment to targeting. The limitation is perception and in the case of certain spells, an impediment to the thing it creates, not to magic as a general thing

79.author: marcus_gideon
79.body:
True, magic in general is not hindered. Magic is a fundamental force, like gravity. It's gonna work whether or not there's a wall in the way.

It depends on the specific spell you're casting. But I suspect there are more spells that would be hindered by a wall, than there are spells willing to go through it for whatever purpose.

Adventurer spells really, I'd be willing to bet that if we had access to all the spells in these worlds, that we would see very different trends. First suggestion - don't try and make an entire world. Instead just make a local kingdom, or even smaller just a local city/town with some adventure type places around (forest, mountains, swamp, etc). Flesh that out before moving on. Besides that you might have a top level idea of what else is in your world, but until it is meaningful to the players' experience, then all that extra planning is moot.

I started with just a local region and keep adding to the map, or expanding it's edges, as the players/characters learn more about the world around them. It started off with them just knowing what was local to their experiences in life thus far, and grows with each new adventure. Gives me time to create things, take player actions into consideration for world-building, lets me focus on what is truly relevant, etc.
